result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt:
11:45 AM Defendant Gerald Michael Erpelding in court.  Attorney Adam Thomas Witt in court for Gerald Michael Erpelding.  Attorney Laura Kohl in court for State of Wisconsin.
State complied with Victim Witness Notification.  Plea Questionnaire filed and reviewed. Court advises defendant of rights.  Elements stated.  Factual basis found.  Defendant advised of U.S. non-citizen collateral consequences resulting in deportation, the exclusion of admission to this country, or the denial of naturalization under federal law.   Joint recommendation for informal probation DPA.  Atty Witt reads prepared statement to the court.  No Contest plea entered on count 2.  Counts 1,3,4 Dismissed.   Court approves the DPA.

11:21 AM Defendant Gerald Michael Erpelding in court with Attorney Adam Thomas Witt in court.  Attorney Laura Kohl in court for State of Wisconsin.
Parties have made progress on negotiating a potential settlement.  Plea date set with PSI not requested by the parties.  Court removes the JT from the calendar.
Plea date scheduled for October 12, 2022 at 11:00 am.
Plea date on October 12, 2022 at 11:00 am.

Prelim questionnaire and waiver. Waiver of preliminary hearing.    Court finds probable cause.  Defendant bound over for trial.    Information filed.  Court advises defendant of charges & penalties.  Not Guilty plea entered.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for May 10, 2022 at 08:30 am.
